name: Mercure Hotel Narita

reviews.text: I have stayed at the Narita Mercure several times over the past 5 years. It may not be the most luxurious hotel by Western standards, nor have the level of amenities of a 4 or 5 star hotel - but, it's not a 4 or 5 star hotel and isn't meant to be luxurious. The location of the hotel could not be better - it's an 8 minute train ride from the Narita terminals plus 1-2 minutes from the arrival platform at the Narita station via Keisei line (about 340¥, I think).
reviews.title: Having seen some other reviews I felt compelled to write one

reviews.text: The REAL upside of staying here is its proximity to the main shopping street (exit the hotel, turn right, walk straight -- that's the main shopping street). The breakfast buffet is definitely not the Marriott Breakfast Buffet - but with a little sense of adventure, you can combine both Western and Japanese foods - and learn a little about adapting to another culture. If you really crave American food, just walk 2-3 minutes down the street to McDonald's. The main street has a fantastic noodle shop - Ramen Bayashi. If you want a substantial and cost-effective dinner, try Hero's Grill House - find the JR Station, then Mister Donuts, then walk to the bottom of the hill on the street between Mister Donuts and the police substation and it's on your left. Both the noodle shop and the grill house are very popular with the airline crews so 1. you know the food is good 2. the prices are reasonable and 3. there will be an English menu. Both restaurants are also very popular with the locals.
reviews.title: See the charm of old town Narita -- and a great shrine

reviews.text: The Narita Mercure is also about 15 minutes down the main shopping street to the Naritasan Temple and park -- INCREDIBLE AND NOT TO BE MISSED. If you stay at hotels nearer to the airport you will not have easy access to the shopping street, restaurants, and temple without a taxi or the bus system.
reviews.title: can't beat location & price

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Stay at the Narita Mercure, take the Keisei Limited Express to Ueno Station and switch to the subway system of Tokyo for a day in the city without the expenses of staying there. Ueno zoo and park are worth a vist - and the museum at Ueno Park also houses some masterpieces of Western art. From the Narita Mercure it's also possible to travel to Kamakura without changing trains (go to the JR station and get the schedule and tickets from the travel office on the right as you enter and pass the little grocery shop.
reviews.title: Good Value for early morning flight

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The Mercure might not be very fancy, but you'll save enough by staying there and taking day trips with the money you DO save.
reviews.title: Truly Awful

reviews.text: This Mercure hotel is only a 20 minute (complimentarty) bus ride from Narita. The rooms are not big but above average for Japanese standard. Large and comfortable queen bed and a pretty small shower/toilet cubicle. The restaurant serves a very good buffet breakfast for 1500 Yen. At dinner time they offered (beside the a la carte menu) a Japanese 5 course menu with Sashimi, Tempura etc. for 2500 Yen - all meals I had were very tasty and worth the money. There is also an indoor pool, fitness centre and sauna, but not complimentary for hotel guests (1000 Yen per visit). Limited express trains to the city are only 2 minutes away (Keisi and JR lines). It takes a bit over an hour to get to Nippori (Keisei Line), then another 10 minutes on JR to Tokyo Station. Within short walking distance there are plenty of other restaurants and one of Japan's largest temple area is worthwhile visiting.
reviews.title: Close to airport and train station, value for money.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We stayed here as a result of the recent air chaos due to the volcanic ash. We liked the location of the hotel as it is close to the Omote-Sando main street full of good bars and resturaunts.
reviews.title: Close to Town, Average Quality, Low Value

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We stayed in 2 rooms, which were ok, but the walls and curtains were stained. BBC News is a great feature if you want to get updates from home. Coin operated internet was awful - it mainly eats your money. If you have a laptop you can pay to connect it to the LAN. And the advertised pool was not free.
reviews.title: Generally shabby; I would not stay there again.

reviews.text: So in summary, the location is good, but its too expensive for what it is. There are better options, but you could do worse. If you like town locations then this is for you, as opposed to some of the other airport hotels which are miles from anything.
reviews.title: Avoid This One

reviews.text: General. We stayed at the Mercure after our flight was delayed and we were put there by the airline. The hotel has an air of shabbiness to it, it is rather tired throughout and the rooms are very small. All the passengers put there were unhappy with the standard of accommodation.
reviews.title: great for airport or quick stay

reviews.text: We stayed 1 night to catch a plane the next morning. I have an A|Plus Gold Card.
reviews.title: Convenient but not more

description: Mercure Hotel Narita is located at Tokyos Narita Airport, a few minutes walk from Kesei rail station. The hotel features 248 rooms, a restaurant, bar, indoor heated swimming pool, gymnasium, squash court and complimentary airport shuttle service. Narita San-Shinshoji Temple, one of the largest temples in Japan, is also nearby.
